albumData.title: 150920 Repairing and reupholstering chairs for Grace

media.description:
Four chairs,
three need new bottoms, 
all need to be reupholstered.
media.title: 20150918_185649.jpg

media.description:
Bottom of the first old chair.
Those old flat head screws are a pain, the slots are shallow and often standard screwdrivers are too thick.
One of these things is not like the others... I love finding mixed fasteners in old furniture too.  
As suspected it was larger, probably to accommodate for a lost screw or stripped screw hole.
The seat is clearly broken through.
media.title: 20150918_185711.jpg

media.description:
Removed chair bottom, clearly made well, pieces are formed nicely, fastened with mortise and tenon joinery.
The old covering was a real pain to get off... it had already been reupholstered so there were two layers of different kinds of little tacks I had to remove.
media.title: 20150918_190656.jpg

media.description:
EXCELSIOR!

At first I thought "What the heck? Is that grass in there?!"
Then I remembered that natural materials were routinely used before the modern synthetic age.
(I actually remembered from a 1990's live production of "Problem Child" starring an all male cast at the Annoyance Theatre in Chicago... possibly the campiest thing I have ever seen.  
Many of you may also remember excelsior from "A Christmas Story", the leg lamp was packed in it.
media.title: 20150918_191812.jpg

media.description: Seat padding to the left, frame and broken bottom to the right.
media.title: 20150918_191933.jpg

media.description:
Traced broke bottom on 1/4" plywood.
The original is 1/8" birch plywood but I don't have any of that on hand.  The 1/4" will be plenty strong and I seriously doubt if anyone will feel the extra 1/4" thickness.
(princess & the pea caliber difference here)
media.title: 20150918_192934.jpg

media.description:
I found the materials this chair seat was made of to be sort of beautiful.  
The batting filled with excelsior, the oxidized broken birch plywood, the well made seat frame with different colored wood pieces and nice rounded over finished edges.
media.title: 20150918_192945.jpg

media.description:
I obviously couldn't fit the entire sheet of plywood into the bandsaw 
so first I rough cut the seat form free with the jigsaw, 
it was hanging off too the right.  
The clamp is to help hold the board still on the table.
media.title: 20150918_193355.jpg

media.description:
Those little tacks were getting everywhere and I don't want to find them in my feet later.
This is a really good trick for picking up nails or iron filings.
I put a magnet in a plastic bag, that way I can pick up whatever I want and later get my powerful magnet back as clean as when I started.
media.title: 20150918_194053.jpg

media.description: Test fit was good, ready to nail the new base to the frame
media.title: 20150918_194612.jpg

media.description: Done and ready to cover.
media.title: 20150918_194636.jpg

media.description:
JoAnn and I worked together to cover the bottom of the chairs with oil cloth featuring lemon branches on a field of deep blue we bought in Sicily seven years earlier.
At this point we're still trying to figure out how to do the corners.
media.title: 20150918_200043.jpg

media.description: Voila!
media.title: 20150918_200347.jpg

media.description: One seat done.
media.title: 20150918_200357.jpg

media.description:
Ta-Da!
One chair done.
media.title: 20150918_200806.jpg

media.description:
Working on the second seat,
Refining technique using screw drivers and cutting away material with utility knife.
The best way I found is almost chiseling the tacks out with the seat pinned against the raised edges of my workbench.
Collection of tacks and nails on the magnet steadily growing.
media.title: 20150918_203455.jpg

media.description: Here is a look at the original seat cover.
media.title: 20150918_203658.jpg

media.description:
HA!  It looks like the seat bottoms are re purposed packing crate material.

Cool
media.title: 20150918_203800.jpg

media.description: Second seat covered.
media.title: 20150918_205104.jpg

media.description: On the third seat I just removed the outer cover and had a look at the original material.
media.title: 20150918_210029.jpg

media.description: It is almost exactly like the material I remember on some chairs my grandparents had when I was little.  It takes me back, but at this point I don't miss it.
media.title: 20150918_210041.jpg

media.description: Last two seats ready for covering!
media.title: 20150918_211045.jpg

media.description: Getting ready to cut the covering to size for each seat.
media.title: 20150918_211108.jpg

media.description:
I swung the magnet-in-a-bag around one last time to pick up the final nails, then
I flipped the bag inside out and remove the magnet.
The magnet is clean, the nails are all in a bag, and I didn't have to touch any of them.
Neat trick

( ...or life hack if you will - I LOVE this guy: 
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCe_vXdMrHHseZ_esYUskSBw )
media.title: 20150918_211342.jpg

media.description:
Four finished chairs.
They look great if I say so myself.
And the pattern turned out as consistently oriented and placed as we had hoped.
Yay!
media.title: 20150918_213738.jpg

media.description: Time for the supervisor to inspect!
media.title: 20150918_213814.jpg

media.description: Decker approaches...
media.title: 20150918_213817.jpg

media.description: ... surveys ...
media.title: 20150918_213820.jpg

media.description: ... and APPROVES!
media.title: 20150918_213823.jpg

media.description: Finished chairs ready to go to Grace & Joes
media.title: IMG_20150919_222904_01.jpeg

media.description:
Chairs in their new home.
They look lovely.
media.title: IMG_20150919_222906_01.jpeg
